qas.question: What helps pilots fly the approach for landing?
What helps pilots find the direction to the airport?
What instruments do pilots use to find the runway and fly the correct approach, even if they cannot see the ground?

plausible_answers.text: helps pilots fly the approach for landing

qas.question: How does distance measuring equipment (DME) help a pilot land?
What also goes along with the VASI?
What determines the distance to the VASI?
Where are DME's also located to help aircraft naviagte?
What is increasing based on the use of VOR?

context: There are a number of aids available to pilots, though not all airports are equipped with them. A <a0_0><a1_0>visual approach slope indicator<a1_0/><a0_0/> (VASI) <b5_0>helps pilots fly the approach for landing<b5_0/>. Some airports are equipped with a <a2_0><a3_0>VHF omnidirectional range<a3_0/><a2_0/> (VOR) to help pilots find the direction to the airport. VORs are often accompanied by a <b6_0><b7_0>distance measuring equipment<b7_0/> (DME)<b6_0/> to determine the distance to the VOR. VORs are also located <b8_0>off airports<b8_0/>, where they serve to provide airways for aircraft to navigate upon. In poor weather, pilots will use an <a4_0>instrument landing system<a4_0/> (ILS) to find the runway and fly the correct approach, even if they cannot see the ground. <b9_0>The number of instrument approaches<b9_0/> based on the use of the Global Positioning System (GPS) is rapidly increasing and may eventually be the primary means for instrument landings.
